speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: SCENE V. The same. A hall in Aufidius's house.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Music within. Enter a Servingman

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Wine, wine, wine! What service

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: is here! I think our fellows are asleep.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Enter a second Servingman

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Where's Cotus? my master calls

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: for him. Cotus!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A goodly house: the feast smells well; but I

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Appear not like a guest.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter the first Servingman

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: What would you have, friend? whence are you?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Here's no place for you: pray, go to the door.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have deserved no better entertainment,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In being Coriolanus.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter second Servingman

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Whence are you, sir? Has the porter his eyes in his

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: head; that he gives entrance to such companions?

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Pray, get you out.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Away!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Away! get you away.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Now thou'rt troublesome.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Are you so brave? I'll have you talked with anon.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Enter a third Servingman. The first meets him

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What fellow's this?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: A strange one as ever I looked on: I cannot get him

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: out of the house: prithee, call my master to him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Retires

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What have you to do here, fellow? Pray you, avoid

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the house.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let me but stand; I will not hurt your hearth.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What are you?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A gentleman.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: A marvellous poor one.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: True, so I am.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Pray you, poor gentleman, take up some other

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: station; here's no place for you; pray you, avoid: come.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Pushes him away

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: What, you will not? Prithee, tell my master what a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: strange guest he has here.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: And I shall.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Where dwellest thou?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Under the canopy.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Under the canopy!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Where's that?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I' the city of kites and crows.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I' the city of kites and crows! What an ass it is!

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Then thou dwellest with daws too?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, I serve not thy master.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: How, sir! do you meddle with my master?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay; 'tis an honester service than to meddle with thy

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: mistress. Thou pratest, and pratest; serve with thy

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: trencher, hence!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Beats him away. Exit third Servingman

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Enter AUFIDIUS with the second Servingman

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Where is this fellow?

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Here, sir: I'ld have beaten him like a dog, but for

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: disturbing the lords within.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Retires

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Whence comest thou? what wouldst thou? thy name?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Why speak'st not? speak, man: what's thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If, Tullus,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Unmuffling

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Not yet thou knowest me, and, seeing me, dost not

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Think me for the man I am, necessity

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Commands me name myself.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: What is thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A name unmusical to the Volscians' ears,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And harsh in sound to thine.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Say, what's thy name?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Bears a command in't; though thy tackle's torn.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Prepare thy brow to frown: know'st

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: thou me yet?

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I know thee not: thy name?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My name is Caius Marcius, who hath done

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To thee particularly and to all the Volsces

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Great hurt and mischief; thereto witness may

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My surname, Coriolanus: the painful service,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The extreme dangers and the drops of blood

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Shed for my thankless country are requited

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: But with that surname; a good memory,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And witness of the malice and displeasure

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which thou shouldst bear me: only that name remains;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The cruelty and envy of the people,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Permitted by our dastard nobles, who

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have all forsook me, hath devour'd the rest;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And suffer'd me by the voice of slaves to be

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whoop'd out of Rome. Now this extremity

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hath brought me to thy hearth; not out of hope--

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Mistake me not--to save my life, for if

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I had fear'd death, of all the men i' the world

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I would have 'voided thee, but in mere spite,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To be full quit of those my banishers,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Stand I before thee here. Then if thou hast

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A heart of wreak in thee, that wilt revenge

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thine own particular wrongs and stop those maims

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of shame seen through thy country, speed

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: thee straight,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And make my misery serve thy turn: so use it

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That my revengeful services may prove

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As benefits to thee, for I will fight

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Against my canker'd country with the spleen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of all the under fiends. But if so be

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Longer to live most weary, and present

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My throat to thee and to thy ancient malice;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which not to cut would show thee but a fool,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Since I have ever follow'd thee with hate,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And cannot live but to thy shame, unless

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: It be to do thee service.

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: O Marcius, Marcius!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: A root of ancient envy. If Jupiter

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Should from yond cloud speak divine things,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And say 'Tis true,' I'ld not believe them more

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Than thee, all noble Marcius. Let me twine

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Mine arms about that body, where against

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: My grained ash an hundred times hath broke

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here I clip

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The anvil of my sword, and do contest

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As hotly and as nobly with thy love

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As ever in ambitious strength I did

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: I loved the maid I married; never man

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Than when I first my wedded mistress saw

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars! I tell thee,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We have a power on foot; and I had purpose

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Twelve several times, and I have nightly since

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: We have been down together in my sleep,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Unbuckling helms, fisting each other's throat,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: From twelve to seventy, and pouring war

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Into the bowels of ungrateful Rome,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Like a bold flood o'er-bear. O, come, go in,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And take our friendly senators by the hands;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Who am prepared against your territories,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Though not for Rome itself.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You bless me, gods!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Therefore, most absolute sir, if thou wilt have

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The leading of thine own revenges, take

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: The one half of my commission; and set down--

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: As best thou art experienced, since thou know'st

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Whether to knock against the gates of Rome,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Or rudely visit them in parts remote,

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: To fright them, ere destroy. But come in:

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Let me commend thee first to those that shall

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Say yea to thy desires. A thousand welcomes!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: And more a friend than e'er an enemy;

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Yet, Marcius, that was much. Your hand: most welcome!

speaker: AUFIDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt CORIOLANUS and AUFIDIUS. The two Servingmen come forward

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Here's a strange alteration!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: By my hand, I had thought to have strucken him with

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: a cudgel; and yet my mind gave me his clothes made a

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: false report of him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: What an arm he has! he turned me about with his

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: finger and his thumb, as one would set up a top.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Nay, I knew by his face that there was something in

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: him: he had, sir, a kind of face, methought,--I

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: cannot tell how to term it.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: He had so; looking as it were--would I were hanged,

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: but I thought there was more in him than I could think.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: So did I, I'll be sworn: he is simply the rarest

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: man i' the world.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: I think he is: but a greater soldier than he you wot on.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Who, my master?

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Nay, it's no matter for that.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Worth six on him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Nay, not so neither: but I take him to be the

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: greater soldier.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that:

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: for the defence of a town, our general is excellent.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Ay, and for an assault too.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Re-enter third Servingman

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: O slaves, I can tell you news,-- news, you rascals!

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: What, what, what? let's partake.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I would not be a Roman, of all nations; I had as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: lieve be a condemned man.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Wherefore? wherefore?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Why, here's he that was wont to thwack our general,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Caius Marcius.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Why do you say 'thwack our general '?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: I do not say 'thwack our general;' but he was always

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: good enough for him.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Come, we are fellows and friends: he was ever too

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: hard for him; I have heard him say so himself.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: He was too hard for him directly, to say the troth

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: on't: before Corioli he scotched him and notched

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: him like a carbon ado.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: An he had been cannibally given, he might have

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: broiled and eaten him too.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: But, more of thy news?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Why, he is so made on here within, as if he were son

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and heir to Mars; set at upper end o' the table; no

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: question asked him by any of the senators, but they

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: stand bald before him: our general himself makes a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: mistress of him: sanctifies himself with's hand and

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: turns up the white o' the eye to his discourse. But

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the bottom of the news is that our general is cut i'

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: the middle and but one half of what he was

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: yesterday; for the other has half, by the entreaty

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and grant of the whole table. He'll go, he says,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and sowl the porter of Rome gates by the ears: he

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: will mow all down before him, and leave his passage polled.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: And he's as like to do't as any man I can imagine.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: many friends as enemies; which friends, sir, as it

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: were, durst not, look you, sir, show themselves, as

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: we term it, his friends whilst he's in directitude.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Directitude! what's that?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: But when they shall see, sir, his crest up again,

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: and the man in blood, they will out of their

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: burrows, like conies after rain, and revel all with

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: him.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: But when goes this forward?

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: drum struck up this afternoon: 'tis, as it were, a

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: parcel of their feast, and to be executed ere they

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: wipe their lips.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: Why, then we shall have a stirring world again.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: This peace is nothing, but to rust iron, increase

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: tailors, and breed ballad-makers.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Let me have war, say I; it exceeds peace as far as

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: day does night; it's spritely, waking, audible, and

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: full of vent. Peace is a very apoplexy, lethargy;

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: mulled, deaf, sleepy, insensible; a getter of more

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: bastard children than war's a destroyer of men.

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: 'Tis so: and as war, in some sort, may be said to

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: be a ravisher, so it cannot be denied but peace is a

speaker: Second Servingman
text_entry: great maker of cuckolds.

speaker: First Servingman
text_entry: Ay, and it makes men hate one another.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: Reason; because they then less need one another.

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: The wars for my money. I hope to see Romans as cheap

speaker: Third Servingman
text_entry: as Volscians. They are rising, they are rising.

speaker: All
text_entry: In, in, in, in!

speaker: All
text_entry: Exeunt
